ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This class will challenge you and requires a large time commitment to do the problem sets (recommend working in groups). However, this is the best opportunity to learn this information at FES, and probably Yale, so it is highly recommended.

While they were time intensive, the problem sets were really helpful in understanding and learning the class material. I would actually say they were the most valuable aspect of the class. However, I should also mention that the problem set instructions could have been written to be clearer. At times, due to grammatical errors, I found myself completely dependent on the TAs to clarify what was expected of us for the assignments.The readings were really comprehensive and served as great resources.
This course provides me a lot of information and I really like the way the instructor analyzing the data.However, sometimes it is very hard for me to follow the instructor because of my English.

Overall, this was a great course. I came from an energy background and this class helped clear up many concepts for me and is a great foundational tool for a (continued) career in the energy industry. Even though I had been speaking the vocabulary for several years, this class taught me the true meaning of the vocabulary that I knew, and helped expound my knowledge of the varying, complex energy fields and arenas throughout the world. A great course, overall. It is demanding, but the professor warns students on Day #1 that the course load is not light, not easy, and will be frustrating. It's worth sweating it out, in the end.
Professor Grubler often goes into hours of lecture with little attention to the energy or responsiveness of the students -- he often simply lectures without engaging students.
This class is helpful for anyone interested in energy. There is a lot of work, but most students know that going into the class.
It was a great course. I highly recommend it.

The homework assignments are a bit difficult and time-consuming but very useful. Supplemental readings were a bit less useful unless they related to a strong personal interest outside of the class. Trips to the power plant, the energy tour of Kroon Hall, and the debates were interesting and educational but not essential to doing well in the class.

Arnulf is a great lecturer and knows his stuff, though sometimes it was overloaded with information and you didnt come away from the class after taking home a few key things.The course work was a little excessive and could have been less quant' heavy.Overall though the best course I took this semester.

The material taught in class did not in any way prepare us for the homework assignments. The problem sets were time consuming and the bulk of the effort spent on them was mining data, not actually understanding concepts. The lectures were more like paternalistic/patronizing rants about the state of energy in the United States rather than actual explanations of processes. I often left with no solid take-a-ways.
Learning how to access, understand, and apply comprehensive energy-related data
Professor Grubler is a wealth of knowledge and manages to cover a lot of material. You will learn something new, no matter your background.
You learn very useful skills in this class, and exercise them a lot.
The readings.
The problem sets are challenging but you learn a lot from the process. Definitely worth it.
Professor Grubler
It changes the way I think.
Grubler, and the fact that he challenges students.
The energy of the lecturer, the vast informational resources available on V2, explanations of why these resources are important, and the spectrum of information and lectures given to students.
that it gave me broader perspective of energy systems.
Instructor and TA are very good and the homeworks allow to apply the knowledge. The readings are helpful for both lectures and homeworks.

The best thing about this course is its interdisciplinary nature. We not only looked at energy supply and demand, but the effect of these on the environment, global warming, health issues, and urbanization.
Some of the readings.
I have s much much better understanding of the energy system now. The materials are very informative. The instructor is a real expert in this field and also a really fun person.
An critical perspective of Energy Systems.
The class offered a great overview of energy related topic and also offered the change to read deeper into topics I was particularly interested in.
one of the best fundamental courses in FES. and may be the best for student with an interest in energy.
Arnulf was a great professor. There was a lot of work but I learned a lot and I found it to be very useful. I enjoyed lectures even though sometimes we moved very quickly through the lectures.
The instructor was engaging, passionate, and interesting. I learned a lot.
The course content
Very insightful comments to the knowledge.

Learning units of energy and calculations to substantiate/inform a general underatanding of energy issues, of climate change, and of specific knowledge that relates to my career in sustainable architecture.
Grubler is an entertaining lecturer and has a very unique and worthwhile perspective.
Getting familiar with important figures and numbers, and learning where to find them.
Covering a lot of introductory energy material. The problem sets were challenging but interesting and informative.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The exams were a test of how well we could find answers in a book rather than an opportunity to demonstrate critical thinking based on themes presented in the course. Similarly with problem sets, the bulk of the time spent working on them involved looking through large documents to find numbers rather than in conceptualizing the problems. Additionally, my background is in science/engineering and spending time doing unit conversions is, frankly, a poor use of time and would be better covered in an introductory chemistry course. I think splitting the difference in material for science and non-science students resulted in tedium for science students and ill-preparedness for non-science students.

Providing more direction as to where to find some data for the problem sets. Occasionally some links or hints were provided, but the data mining, while an important part of research, adds a great deal of time to an already very time intensive homework assignment.
The explanations of the homework; both in order to prepare to answer them and then also to understand what it is the homework is asking you to do (the questions were often unclear).
Arnulf needs to tighten up the lectures. His rants are interesting, but we had to come in for 5 extra hours of class because he was so far behind.He can still do some ranting but keep track of time.
The lecture slides are clear but Arnulf tends to go off in tangents that are not only confusing, but takes away from the class.

Some of the problem sets could have less of a data-research component and more focus on the analysis and math. Also, the lectures were sometimes fairly dis-connected from the problem sets. More lecture time could have been spent on how we were supposed to do the calculations and answer problems like those given in the problem set.

The problems sets for this course are RIDICULOUS. Obscene! Preposterous! Lilliputian math problems! What in the world is the point? We all know how to spend countless hours slogging through spreadsheets and data-mining--do we really need to do it 6 times? Why not short papers on the concepts presented, or at least problem sets with a more conceptual bent. I just think it's a shame because the concepts are so fascinating and worthwhile, but in terms of homework we spend 1% of our time thinking about the concepts and 99% of our time dredging up all the statistics that prove them.

The problem sets can require upwards of 20+ hours and not all of the material or concepts are covered in class. The biggest problem with the problem sets is the delay time between when the material is covered in class and when the problem sets are assigned. Sometimes there is a lag or delay of a few weeks, which makes the relevancy of the problem sets compromised sometimes (but not always).
The concepts asked in assignments should be discussed later in detail in the class as well.

Problem sets could require an excess of 20 hours to complete, with much of that time often searching online for very specific data. This required far too much time finding one point of data rather than working through course concepts.

The form that the course is graded is not according to a professional-master course. The exam does not allow to apply any knowledge because is more memorize test instead of test /paper of a master program . The tests of this course decrease the depth that may reach.Also, once, we had 11 hours of lectures during one week because there was a incoordination of some professional lectures. It is not positive for students to have these amount of lectures during one week. The next semester professor should plan better the numbers and times of lerctures.

The problem sets could be improved by making the directions clearer and providing more guidance on where to find some of the information needed for the problem sets. Sometimes, these problem sets would take so long because our groups would spend a lot of time looking for the right metric online since there was no recommended organization/source provided.
The homework while helpful in some cases seemed unnecessarily time consuming. Having to spend hours looking up information just to make a simple calculation didn't seem like the best use of homework.

The organization of the class according to the material was not clear from the beginning. Students had a hard time getting the pace of the class.Another point is that the problem sets are very long, taking over 15hours do one, not because of conceptual issues but because of the difficulty in understanding the questions [they are not in a clear language]as it is posed and finding a reliable data to use.

The problem sets sometimes ended up being very time intense. This was mainly due to research of single statistical values, which offered no additional insight. This time could be spend on other material
exams should require more critical thinking and less memorization of specific numbers.
needs to be more interactive. like we're being talked at the whole time. problem sets take WAY too much time mining for data instead of doing the analysis that is useful.
The TA's weren't that helpful to email questions. They wrote vague responses and took a long time to grade the assignments -- one was even returned after the final exam.
Clarity of instructions
A little heavy!!

Grubler insults American students (or maybe just those at Yale (and for the record, most of it was probably spot-on) and he does not seem terribly concerned with student learning. He refused to give us our midterms back so that nobody would give the midterm to next year's students. Thus, instead of changing the tests and allowing us to learn from our tests, we got nothing out of the tests.Homeworks were obscenely long at times and not terribly helpful unless I am going to do energy research for my career. I was confused by the focus on knowing where data is, rather than analytical understanding. I got the feeling Grubler was too lazy to grade papers.
class notes need more explanation, especially climate change one. So many figures lack explanation.
I suggest a group project or more problem sets rather than a cramming marathon, which is not conductive to long-time learning, for a midterm and a final.

Lectures and problem sets should be aligned to emphasize key take-aways and concepts rather than having one be an exercises in listening to one side of the argument on the energy debate and the other an exercise in how much time/effort a student is willing to put into data mining.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The TA's were very accessible and the instructor makes a great deal of effort to interact with students outside of the classroom experience, which was appreciated, and fun
The TAs were available and helpful.
The Professor and both TA's were very accessible and helpful.
TA sessions would have been helpful.
Didn't try to contact Arnulf much, but he seemed very accessible. He gave great comments before an extra-credit presentation.TA's were also helpful, giving review sessions, etc.
I never sought help from Arnulf but Simon was a great TA. He was always accessible and his explanations were clear. Erin was really hesitant about offering much help.
Great!
Both the TA and Instructor were available and eager to help, if need be.
Instructor was approachable.
They were always available to solve any doubts.
I did not seek help from the professor outside of class, but the TAs were very responsive to any question.
Both very responsive with many office hours and quick responses.
Both were responsive and helpful.
They were very good in replying to the questions as soon as possible.
TAs and instructor were very helpful and always open to questions and suggestions.
availability- really good. quality- can be improved.
Arnulf and the TAs were very approachable. If Erin and Simon didn't know something, they looked it and got back to us.
Instructor, great. TA, needed improvement.
Good
Simon and Erin made themselves available regularly at scheduled times, and also on an as-needed basis around Kroon. They provided very useful hints and information about problem sets and exams.
TAs were very available and quick to help with our problem sets.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Knowing how to use the lingo of the energy world is valuable in industrial ecology, policy, climate change work, private sector/business consulting, to name a few, so this class is vital for any of those interests.

I'm interested in climate change work, so this class was incredibly important to my academic knowledge base. It's extremely important to understand energy systems, and though Arnulf is pretty intense, he's extremely knowledgable and wants students to learn as much as possible.
Great and crucial course if you are interested in energy.
Help me with data analysis.Learn how the energy system in human society works.
It is not required for my degree (MEM), but would be if I elect to pursue a specialization in the energy track.
I intend to major in energy policy and environmental economics. Therefore, this course is very important for my overall program.
Since I plan to focus on energy, this class was critical for my overall education.
This class really got me interested in energy now.
For me it was a introductory class in Energy. Often, I got lost in some references.
Perfect introduction to understand the broader context of the energy sector and to deepen my study into energy topics.
I am interested in working in the energy field.
Good introductory material. Necessary for energy track.

will design sustainable buildings and cities. An essential component of this is energy, and understanding the entire energy system from resource extraction to final use in order to choose the most appropriate solutions in each situation.
It fits perfect for MEM degree holders who are interested in energy
Energy concentration.

Took the course because energy is such a big component of sustainable urban economic development. It provided a good starting off point for learning the language/an initial framework of the entire energy system (not just the supply side, but also demand), and some context for the global energy crisis, as well as some good resources to use for global expenditures. However, I wish the class had delved more into conceptual explanations. I would have also gotten more out of the problem sets/completed them fully, had they not required an additional ten extra hours of data mining. While I appreciate that in the real world, part of our work will be culling data from reliable resources and knowing where/how to research, many of us will also be in positions where we will have staff culling the data or have been given a mound of data to sort through. The problem sets would be more useful if we had more time to spend on the analysis of data versus just the gathering of data.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: The course sounded like it would treat energy systems from an interesting perspective, and this was partially executed, however, the discussion of the energy system from demand to production seemed to me disjointed.
To be more fluent in units and conversions of energy, and better understand how energy systems work.
I took this course because I wanted an introduction to energy and to systems thinking, which is exactly what I got.
To learn about energy systems.
I was interested in energy and wanted to explore the subject area as a potential career field.
To learn more about the energy sector
Actually I chose this course because I had no background in this area so I can learn something absolutely NEW.
Personal interest, opportunity to build on personal experience, recommendations from previous years' students.
To strengthen my understanding of fundamentals of energy sector.
See the previous question.
Interested in pursuing a career in energy sector.
Wanted to get a taste of energy.
As an introduction to Energy related topics.
I want to specialize in energy during my time at FES.
I am interested in energy yet I lack foundational knowledge.
Reputation.
Do learn the basics of energy systems
To know how to design or evaluate the energy performance for buildings and cities.
I heard great things about it.
Gain understanding in energy basics.
see above

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: No

Yes - my only qualification is that if the homework load wasn't quite so intense I would have liked to spend the same amount of time really going through all the concepts to ensure I've absorbed them.
Yes, it was a great course and I recommend it to everyone.
Yes. For me, this was one of the best classes I've taken at FES.
Yes, but I didn't expect such a focus on climate change and soft sciences.
Yes, I knew that the course was extremely challenging, but expected to work hard and learn a lot from it.

This class presented many headaches but in retrospect, I'm glad I took the class as I learned a lot through the problem sets and realized that what was expected from us in terms of assignments very much mirrors the real world.
Yes, I learned a lot, though I also already knew some of the material.
Yes, though I did really bad in mid term exam (as I didn't bring hard copy with me and the cell phone was not allow to use), I never regret for choosing this course.
Yes, it was a good course. Challenging, sometimes frustrating, but a great way to wipe my slate clean, so to speak, and learn or re-learn energy concepts and fundamentals.
It could be better structured ! We could not go in depth of many topics.
The course is very helpful however the way it is graded is not according to a professional master course.
Yes, I learned a lot in this class (more than expected, since I had been working in the energy efficiency world for several years).
Yes, I really enjoyed this course and felt like I learned a ton.
It
Yes, exceeded my expectations
Yes.
Completely, the best course I attended this semester.
Yes!
Yes.
Yes, absolutely. Great, great course.
Yes.
Yes, itlived up to my expectations and exceeded them.
Not entirely, but its still one of the best classes I've taken at FES.
Yes
yes
Yes.
see above

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: No
Yes
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, the problem sets were difficult but they were very valuable.
If I had put more time into some of the problem sets I may have gotten more out of it but many of them were so long that I wasn't able to set aside enough time to complete them.
Yes.
Yes.
Kind of !
See previous question.
Yes
No, but that being said I had really high expectations. I'm sure ill realize I learned a lot but I dont feel very knowledgeable.
No. I expected to have a more defined path of learning.
Yes, it even exceeded my expectations. It introduced me to new topics and allowed me to discuss topics deeper, which I had studied before.
yes, and more.
Yes. I wish I put more time into this class because you could honestly take only this one class, do all the readings and still need time to fully grasp everything.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes
yes
Yes.
see above

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Group work wasn't required, but we created a study group for the problem sets. It was great to have others to bounce ideas and brainstorm while looking for relevant data sets.Not much disadvantage since it wasn't required. Worked with the group as much as I wanted or didn't want to.
Advantage: Really helpful in understanding the concepts.
Slogging through the problem sets would have been incredibly difficult, if not impossible, without a dedicated and cohesive group effort.
Group work was very indispensable in working on assignments. Since many concepts were new and tricky , group activity helped us sail through.

It was essential to work with groups for the problem set due to the difficulty and amount of time it took to find resources and solve the problems. The only disadvantage was that the problem sets took so much time that a group has a higher tendency to get distracted when working for that long of a time.
Made friends and did a better job on problem sets
Adv: solving the problem sets faster.Dist.: copying some ideas because I had no time to think too much about the question.

Initially the members of the group were working at different paces, which made the overall process quite slow.We decided to split up the group in order for everyone to work at their own pace. If open questions remained, we would all get together to discuss and explain them.
I worked with students on the problem sets and on the exams and found this to be not only helpful but necessary.
Group work was encouraged for problem sets which was helpful.
comparing answers for problem sets. sometimes calculation mistakes lead to ridiculously high or low numbers that are not close to right answers.
You learn more by working in a group.
to divvy up the data mining. to decipher the actual questions being posed by the problem set.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Make sure that energy is what you are interested in; this is not an introductory course but a semester-commitment to letting energy rule your life and take much time away from other classes.

Read the Energy Primer early, and then read it again before the midterm, and then once again before the final. It will help tie all the information together for you and ensure it all sinks in.Also, start the problem sets early and work with a small group more the greatest efficiency.
Be prepared to put significant hours into the problem sets.
Make sure you start the problem sets early, and find a group of people that know something about energy.
Start the problem sets early and ask the TAs for help whenever possible. It's also really, REALLY helpful to work in groups.
Leave a long time for the problem sets.
Think actively.
Get organized and call a general strike on the problem sets.

Be prepared for a heavy workload, but to learn a lot. I would say that if the student just has a passing interest in energy and is taking the course "just to be a good environmentalist," they may be frustrated by the time commitment the course requires and by the sometimes disjointed lectures and flow of the course. Overall, I would recommend it, though.
Do all the readings !!!

Be prepared to spend a frustrating amount of time completing problem sets that cover material that was not directly taught in the classroom. Find others to work with, or else you'll be lost on your own.

The course is very useful because lectures and professor are very well prepared. The TA are available to solve any doubts specially those ones for homeworks.The homeworks are a good way to apply the knowledge learned by lectures and readings.The exams are memorize the readings, thus tests do not help in order to learn.
Work with groups on the problem sets and start early.
Try to keep up on the reading. He will ask really obscure numbersin the readings be prepared. Know that homework will easily take you longer than 9 hours to complete.
Don't complain about the workload, it is worthwhile and manageable.
Do the readings from the beginning do the PS in groups and as soon as possible; be ready to not understand the PS and fell free to ask the TA's.
Do not get discourage by the initial work load you can benefit very much by following the course. The overall concept of the course is very good.

prepare to spend more than 10 hours on each problem set. prepare also to feel like you are only taking one class! but the knowledge gained in the class is very rewarding, and it provides the basics needed to get into the energy realm.
Don't wait until the last minute to start your problem sets or study for the exams.
Be prepared to work hard on problem sets and do the reading prior to the lectures. The professors slides are posted online, butare very difficult to follow without prior knowledge.
Overall, a good course.

Start problem sets a week early and make friends with TFs, second-year students who already took the course, with Arnulf, and with anyone who can help you understand the material. It will all be worth it in the end :)
work in groups.try to answer most of the problem set but don't be frustratedeven if you can't finish them.
Work in groups and don't stress too much.

A lot of the key-take-aways you will have to draw for yourself. The class tests your ability to memorize Grubler's Energy Primer and willingness to data mine versus actual understanding of global concepts/issues/theories re: current energy crisis
